key_points: Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th president of the United States, emphasizing democracy's triumph and calling for unity.
Kamala Harris made history as the first woman, first Black person, and first person of South Asian descent elected to the vice presidency.
Biden's inauguration took place with heightened security and no crowds due to the pandemic and recent Capitol siege.
Over 200,000 American flags were planted on the National Mall to represent those who couldnâ€™t attend the inauguration.
Biden indirectly rebuked Trump in his speech, focusing on democracy, unity, and the challenges America faces such as COVID-19, economic strain, and racial injustice.
Biden signed a series of executive actions on his first day, including rejoining the Paris Climate Accords and instituting a mask mandate on federal property.
Former Presidents Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, and Barack Obama attended the inauguration, highlighting bipartisan support.
Biden enters office with a plan for an ambitious first 100 days, focusing on combating the pandemic and economic relief.
The inauguration ceremony included performances by Lady Gaga and others, with a focus on national unity and healing.
The absence of crowds and the presence of a large security force marked this as an unusual inauguration.
